Thank you, Madam President, Mrs. Commissioner. The current financial crisis shows us well that when the problem is global, we need a global response.

It turns out that it does not work out perfectly as we would like because we are faced with a problem that is as follows: we have to advise on two things – the necessary free trade which everyone agrees on, but also the protections which are just as necessary.
And protection of national economies or agriculture does not mean protectionism.
The path we have chosen for sixty years, since the GATT, is an unbalanced one that goes from reducing customs duties with the objective of their elimination.
It is found that technically, the reduction of customs duties.
It's difficult! Proof – a whole series of mathematical formulas – the South Korean formula, the European formula, or the most well-known formula, the Swiss formula.
It does not really work because a product is not unique.
It consists of many elements with very different rules of origin, and technically reducing customs duties is not as simple as one might think.
Therefore, we are facing a technical impasse, and we are trying politically through negotiations to find a way out of this impasse.

Yet, it turns out that technologically, scientists have invented a new customs technology – the deducible customs duty technology – which allows exporters to deduct customs duties from the economy of the importing state.
Concretely, this deductible customs right transforms into an equal customs credit for the amount of customs duty that the exporter has borne in the important country.
This is a three-character tax credit that is refundable, negotiable, and convertible.
It is refundable when the exporter buys from the importer; he can deduct the customs duty he has borne.
It is negotiable because if the exporting company that has supported customs duties with nothing has nothing to buy from the importer, it negotiate its customs debt on the bond market or in bank.
And it is beneficial if we want to help developing countries; the importer can offer a higher amount of customs credit than the sum of duties.
Well, with this technique, we create an international trade currency whose monetary mass is equal to the amount of existing customs duties.
For example, the European Union would offer thirteen billion euros in international trade.

Dear Mr President, Mr Barroso, Mr Vondra, dear colleagues, our Group fully supports with enthusiasm the Small Business Act project that the Commission presented to us last June.

Certainly, since the year 2000, initiatives have been taken in the direction of SMEs, and I am thinking particularly of the excellent work done by our colleague Dominique Vlasto on the Charter of SMEs. These initiatives were appreciated but judged insufficient because they often remained at the wishful thinking stage.

Systematic impact assessments should be carried out regularly with the European Parliament monitoring the application of the Small Business Act in the Member States.

Good Conduct Code has no binding force; we should be more imaginative, more inventive, and propose concrete measures adapted to really open up access to these markets for SMEs.

It is therefore the treasure of SMEs that is at risk, and we must consequently ensure to support their activities by ensuring that banks guarantee effective access to the financing necessary for the continuity of their operations.

European, in order for this principle to be made effective now, we must go beyond the declaration, we must implement it in all European policies and programs.
However, we can say that this action plan is a real response to the urgency of the situation.

All overtime hours shall be counted as working time.

It is a question of common sense to ensure decent working conditions, especially for medical professionals.
But the reform of the Working Time Directive also gives us an opportunity to make progress with our European social rights by eliminating the individual opt-out.
The Cercas report takes this opportunity and proposes a progressive abolition of all possibilities of defying the maximum legal duration of working time.
We have to look reality in the face.
It is a truism to say that an employee finds themselves in a situation of equality with their employer and can refuse what is offered to them.
Dear colleagues, we must clearly show the Member States that the text they wish to impose on us is unacceptable.

In the tribute concert that will certainly be heard by the French Government tomorrow, I think it is necessary above all to focus on the employees who will be called upon to work even more without really having a choice, and this like everyone else who will be asked to work on Sundays in France from now on.

It is true that Mr. Cashman has been working tirelessly over the years and negotiating with skill, particularly during the trilogue.

It is also true that the directive has made significant progress in terms of improving the functioning of the internal market, collective management of financial assets, and is welcomed as such by the European investment industry.

It remains that debates and discussions in the Council and Parliament were never entirely free since the outcome was known in advance for some actors; it was therefore necessary, at all costs, to introduce the European passport for management companies.
In principle, there is nothing to add; the passport must be defended. However, it is also necessary to ensure that the introduction of passports for management companies is

However, I regret to note that the system established is not only complex but also subject to varying interpretations.
They risk quickly running into practical difficulties which will harm the European industry, particularly in exports to non-EU countries.
I have taken full account of my minority position; nevertheless, I do not feel uncomfortable.
In normal times, I would have been tempted to say that it is only practice that will allow us to draw definitive conclusions on this matter and thus determine
Between those who trust in the adaptation capacities of market players and those who maintain a more cautious approach.

The associations have been desperately fighting for decades just to finally, in 2007, see directives installed in this area where one can see that the Member States exhibit a certain laxity.
I would even dare to say that there is some bad will since, after all, we know that the implementation of controls and inspections is absolutely not insurmountable.
We know the sites of deforestation, we know the areas of grazing, we know the routes of cattle traffic then where is the problem?

I believe it is important in our time, when public opinion is increasingly sensitive - quite rightly so - to animal welfare, whether at the level of breeding conditions, logging, or transport, that states respect these feelings.

And since I have been given the floor, I would like to add something regarding transport. It would be essential to focus on and take into account, regardless of the duration of transportation, local climatic conditions.
Indeed, a several-hour transport carried out in the Netherlands in spring has nothing to compare with the same period of transport in full summer in a country such as Greece.
In these latter cases, night-time transport should not be imposed.
Thank you for considering this proposal in the future.

We all fought for the closure of Guantánamo and we were all delighted with President Obama's decision to close this shameful prison.
Today, the question of receiving Guantánamo inmates should not be a problem for us.
As Europeans committed to our values of protecting human rights, we must take responsibility because it is our duty to welcome these ex-detainees.
We have read – and I am speaking now to the Council – we have read in the press that some Member States were not very keen on this reception.
I would like to make a real appeal to the Council, particularly to those Member States who are hesitant, to accept the fact that these people will be held on their territory.

And I would say to you, dear colleagues, that the worst thing would be if the good will unleashed by the closure of Guantánamo were not to flourish because we did not respond when Europe was called upon.

The European animal feed industry is important because it is one of the largest sectors in agriculture in terms of production; it represents half of EU agricultural production (120 million tonnes), which is more than just a figure - around €50 billion.
The European Union indeed has five million farmers and sixty million households owning companion animals.

In the past, the European Union has had to manage a number of health crises, which means that we must now be more vigilant about transparency in order to meet the expectations of farmers but also of consumers.

The provisions laid down in this report have the advantage of representing minimal costs for industry and great benefits for consumers who are increasingly attentive to the quality of the products they buy.

The adoption of this report will help to mitigate risks by ensuring better product quality, better controls, greater traceability, and a great deal of information for the farmer and ultimately for the consumer.
In today's world, with the growth of international trade, it is imperative to strengthen all preventive measures so that food crises like those we have witnessed in the past do not recur.

This report strikes a balance between the right to information and the need to strictly define the nutritional elements that must be mandatory on labels, as well as the importance of intellectual property rights in preserving the competitiveness of our industries.

I believe that manufacturers should be required to immediately notify the use of any new raw material entering the composition of animal feed in order to ensure transparency and facilitate control by competent authorities.
Including an urgent procedure that allows the introduction of a new dangerous substance into the list of prohibited substances seems to me to be absolutely essential.

The same applies to giving the trader the possibility to question the competent national authority or the European Commission in case of doubt as to an alleged unfair practice, which allows for better verification of systems while protecting the client and preserving the loyalty of commercial transactions.

I therefore wish to lend my full support to this excellent report, as experience shows that regulation on the labelling of animal feed, focusing on quality, transparency, traceability and control, is the best safeguard against new health crises in Europe.

The report I am presenting to Parliament seeks to explain that in the fight against climate change, agriculture has a place and a role to play.
The Nature reminds us this week that, and volcanoes in particular, can have a major impact on human activities and on climate.
But it requires, above all, that men and Europe in particular take their responsibility to combat what we call climate change.
My report attempts to show that agriculture can both continue to reduce its carbon emissions, reduce its consumption of fossil fuels, and above all from another angle.
On the other hand, we should participate very actively in setting carbon emissions limits and fighting globally against less waste and more CO2 fixed and sequestered.
This report attempts to show that in agriculture, we should move away from a 'compartmentalised' approach, which consists of opening up a directive every time there is a problem.
On the floors, on the water, on the pesticides – what else do I know? And try to address the agricultural question with the ambition to treat it in a global and systemic manner.
In this approach, we must be able to find ways to ensure that agriculture, as I said earlier, not only reduces its energy consumption but also participates very actively in carbon sequestration.
It is particularly the role linked to photosynthesis, biomass, and then above all what I keep in mind, which is also related to soil, to this capacity that European soils have to fix organic carbon.

I believe that the path I am opening up in this report – and which I hope will be followed when the vote takes place in plenary in Strasbourg – must allow European agriculture to enter a phase of sustainability, to ensure a future.

Ecological transition to this agriculture which would put it ahead of other continents or other agricultural practices in order to make sure that it is capable of being economically performing, ecologically performing – and I think also from that moment on socially performing.

This report deals with a specific issue, namely the fight against climate change and agriculture, but it is intended – I hope at least – to open up other perspectives, particularly to feed the debate on the future of agricultural policy after 2013.
I will address the Commission; I often address the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development; I will also address different ministers when I have the opportunity to do so.
I think we need to take a turn.
The 2013 agreement must be ambitious.
It must be based on objectives that enable citizens to understand why we need a common agricultural policy.
We need a common agricultural policy because Europe's agriculture must ensure both food security and commit to sustainability.
In any case, that is what I propose in this report, and it is on this basis that I hope Parliament will follow me by a large majority.

Madam President, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to speak and not go back over the debate as it has developed so far.
We have discussed a 2011 budget with the constraints that we know, namely those of a deep crisis throughout Europe, with public deficits at national level which can lead to two hypotheses.
These public deficits at national level constrain the European deficit, where these deficits at national level must give a new orientation and a new impulse at European level.

To remain totally preoccupied by the context of the crisis, except to tell myself – and to tell all European citizens – that, decidedly, Europe will remain in the crisis for a long time.
All our problems stem from effectively managing the crisis and reducing our deficits and debt, but they also involve preparing for an exit from the crisis.
And that is where the budgetary question arises.

We will not be able to emerge from the crisis unless the European budget, because it is European, is capable of giving us the means to find what we lack today: growth, job creation, innovation, research.

This is the issue at stake, and it is at this juncture that we need to discuss the budget, rather than constantly integrating the crisis and deficit issues, as we have done far too often. The Council is excellent in this regard.

I noticed that in Douville, Angela Merkel and Nicholas Sarkozy even announced in advance a reform of the treaties without even having discussed anything with Mr Van Rompuy, just to penalize all those Member States who would not respect tomorrow a budgetary discipline.

Here we are at the Council level today, where Parliament is asking for one thing in particular from the Commission - to try and pull the European project out of its difficulties, and this is happening through the budget.
We have noted a certain number of points on which we are in complete agreement.
There needs to be more flexibility.
Evidently, we need to find together a much more flexible budget because it is a matter of necessity and Europe's responsiveness that is at stake.
It is also, of course, about setting priorities and organizing the efficiency of the European budget.
We will all agree on that, we will all agree, it is a necessity.
But where we have to be clear among us, it is that we need a calendar, we need to set ourselves common objectives, Mr President. This cannot just remain words, commitments, promises.

I would like to emphasize that the issue of third country treatment should be observed in two ways, both inside and outside the European Union.
Thanks in part to the European Parliament, all funds that will be sold within the European Union will effectively be subject to equivalent regulation.
One can then speak more or less about 'level playing field'.
During the transitional period, non-EU entities will benefit from the national placement regime, whereas EU funds and management will be subject to the directive which is generally more stringent.
The situation is different on markets outside the European Union where European funds and their management will remain subject to the directive, which is not the case for third country funds.
It would then be much more difficult to sell European products in the rest of the world because they will be less flexible and more rigid.
We must be aware of this disadvantage even if it was inevitable for a while.

In the beginning of the 21st century, patients need appropriate information so that they can be fully involved in their care path; know where and how to seek care; decide on the best treatment in agreement with healthcare professionals; and strictly follow the prescribed treatment plan.
Today, patients are demanding independent, comparative information and adapted to their needs.
Regrettably, the proposals for revising the directive transmitted by the European Commission did not correctly address the needs expressed by European citizens.

It signifies, on the contrary, an increase in expenditure and taking risks with patients, as opposed to additional bureaucracy.
It is for these reasons that we initially presented a proposal to withdraw these texts, thereby asking the Commission to reconsider its copy.

The tendency for agricultural prices and primary agricultural inputs to increase has been a long-term trend that will continue for three main reasons: the world's demographic evolution and increasing

In its Europe 2020 strategy, the European Union has set the objective of making our economy greener and our transport more modern.

The European Ombudsman is conducting investigations with enthusiasm on complaints against EU institutions and bodies.

Inclusive implementation of the twelve priority proposals of the Single Market Act, the twelve proposals made by the Commission, in respect of which recognition of professional qualifications.

Thank you Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues. I would like first of all to clarify the cost of unfounded allegations about circulation in France of five hundred thousand to one million false biometric passports which would circulate in our country.
France takes very seriously the risks of fraud concerning identity documents.
They do not lightly treat delinquents in this matter.
The theft of identity is punishable by one year in prison and a fine of fifteen thousand euros at the initiative of his Government.
The conditions for delivering identity documents have been simplified, which has allowed the Prefectures to release additional resources to combat this fraud.
Thus, in each prefecture, there is appointed a fraud reference person.
In addition, the security arrangements for the issuance of identity documents have been strengthened.
For example, civil status data could be verified between administrative services as much as possible in a dematerialized manner in order to minimize the risk of falsification.
Some birth certificates are also issued on secure paper.
The same rigor applies to justified domestic claims.
The Ministry of the Interior has committed itself to increasing security checks on residence permits with the insertion of a code bar.

The classic treatment of a title claim includes the authorized consultation of useful documents, the comparison of all the parts produced during previous title claims, and the possible identification of justifiable parts.

The security of title delivery is also ensured by the double coincidence of the applicant at the time of deposit of the application and subsequently the withdrawal of the title as well as the collection of two digital impressions.
And that's not mentioning enhanced checks for the renewal of lost and stolen licenses in a comparative manner with data stored by prefectures. I'll conclude.

In addition, France communicates to international cooperation agencies, especially Interpol, Mr President – almost finished – passports delivered or lost and stolen so that they are not used for fraudulent purposes.
Dear colleagues, as indeed does the rest of the European Union, France is committed.

The President. Madam Commissioner, first of all, let me make a remark. Our fellow citizens increasingly want to find and consume locally produced foodstuffs that are in season, for reasons of health and quality, above all.
We must find ways to enable farmers to respond effectively and quickly to this growing demand.

We must support the implementation of local infrastructure for producers, such as keeping nearby abattoirs, which, while ensuring regular health checks, allows the development of local circuits and strengthens direct sales.
Support local and direct sales must help producers to sell their products and make them known to consumers.
The strengthening of these direct relationships will enable farmers to keep a larger share of the added value created by their operations.

We should promote and facilitate direct sales within farms and support collective actions by farmers who wish to open collective selling points allowing them to offer local consumers a wider range of products.

The European Commission must facilitate the emergence, persistence and development of direct sales systems to consumers such as AMAPs in France, which enable nearly 3,000 farmers to feed some 60,000 families.

Finally, Member States should be able to add other criteria concerning in particular the size of the holding, the volume of production or the traditional nature of the product to define 'close-by' agriculture.

Thank you Mr President, I would like to start by congratulating the European Commission, and particularly yourself, Commissioner, for your unwavering commitment to relaunching and deepening the internal market at the top of the European agenda.

The European Commission and the European Parliament have been working for over two years now to identify the gaps in the internal market and the issues and sectors where more needs to be done to create more growth, competitiveness, and jobs.

The European Council, for its part, has also, albeit somewhat belatedly, signified the immense importance it attached to the rapid and effective implementation of the twelve priority proposals for the internal market and the twelve growth levers.
Instead of constantly trying to invent new growth tools, we have every interest in working with the tool box we already possess.

We therefore seize the opportunity of the resolution that will be put to the vote tomorrow in our Assembly to send a strong political message to the Member States: more speed and efficiency in the transposition of Directives already.

Adopted – more mobilisation and commitment in new fields of activity – I will mention just one, that of enhancing workers’ mobility, making it easier to move around, and increasing fluidity of movement.
We look forward with great interest to the second stage of the single market act that you will present after the summer, Commissioner.
We will prove both political will and ability to put pressure on the Member States.
We have known about the scandal of the Mediator some time ago.
We now have the scandal of mad cow disease which unfortunately highlights, as you said, Commissioner, the malfunctions in European health security.
This scandal of the 'implants mère' - these fourteen years of cover-ups, from 1996 to 2010 – went unpunished.
It's 500,000 prostheses worldwide, it's 8,000 rejections of implants, 48 cases of cancer detected.
It is finally 3,500 complaints. This figure is true, shocking.

Despite warnings from the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), Mr Commissioner, and numerous complaints and convictions for prosthetic implant failures in Great Britain and France, how could national and European agencies have overlooked such a scam?
This tragedy immediately led us to reflect on the improvement of the European system for controlling medical devices, as you explained it just now.
We must, Mr President, build a new system capable of avoiding a scandal today, but it is a new system that we need to build.
It is announced for the autumn – you had indicated this new legislation.
As co-editor of this resolution, I am naturally satisfied with it.
But Mr President, you seem to want to take account of most of our concerns as set out in this resolution.
So why make an exception that is unacceptable to many Members present here?
Why not want the creation of an authorization for placing on the market for Class III medical devices, the most risky?
Mr Dalli, could you explain your position?
The President. We are currently experiencing an increase in production of more than two and a half percent, while at the same time industries are lowering prices.
In Italy, Germany, the UK and throughout Europe, prices have fallen.
This means that prices are directly linked to production volumes, and we need to organize production volumes and, at the same time, prices.
At the same time, today, producers are victims of an increase of more than 44% for vegetable proteins and 30% for cereals.
Parliament has already voted on the need here to ensure that the added value is distributed among producers and that farmers are not victims of companies and large distribution networks.

Therefore, I call on the Commission today, but also on the Council, to reconsider the issue of production control, but at the same time, I say very clearly that the Member States must sort it out themselves, because there are countries that have respected the rules on quotas and others that have not.
It was also what led to these quotas being called into question.
Therefore, there is a double responsibility, both from the Commission and the Member States.

Here is a fine policy where European construction is at the heart of the concerns of Europeans every day.

Financial flows between managers and operators within integrated companies must be made more transparent. There should also be non-discriminatory access for some companies.

But let me make one point. We must stop considering, especially from the European Commission's perspective, the liberalisation of the federal sector as the sole strategic horizon for the development of a single European air space; instead, we must decide on an integrated European investment strategy that is conducive to employment in Europe.

Justice! Not only do these statements seem to misrepresent the Treaties but, above all – and this is what I want to denounce – they show an unacceptable contempt for the European Parliament, for democracy in general, and for the citizens that we represent.

Here is the English translation:
"Let us be clear, European citizens together."
Mr President, by this time many things will have been said.
Thank you very warmly, Commissioner.
Owing to your obstinacy and your tricks of procedure, you are allowing us to demonstrate the importance of the European Parliament as a co-legislator.
Thank you, Commissioner, for having pushed hundreds of thousands of citizens to take to the streets and two million eight hundred thousand to sign petitions.
They have discovered that democracy works here, that our elected European representatives are the representatives of the people, their representatives.
Thank you once again to the millions of internet users who followed the debates and votes in committee, and who continue to follow us today.
I greet them; it is a breath of fresh air in our institutions, which are often perceived as technocratic.
Thank you Mr President but in democracy it is also another principle.
The fundamental principle is that of responsibility.
Tomorrow we will take our responsibility, and I would also like to thank you tomorrow for taking your responsibility, your failure, the failure of your method of work.
Madam President, colleagues, I speak on behalf of Maurice Pongaravella, rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development on Mr Gallagher's report.
When Mrs. Barroso wishes to impose sanctions on a country that practices unsustainable fishing, she must take account of its level of development.

In fact, in accordance with the principle of consistency of policies with development objectives, it is crucial, in my opinion, that the measures adopted in relation to fishing do not undermine the development plans and strategies established by the European Union in those countries.
The draft report by Mr Gallagher takes up this important idea for our Committee on Development by providing that measures should not be unjustified or even discriminatory.

Therefore, I urge the European Commission, when adopting such measures, to respect this principle of policy coherence with development objectives and to take account of the level of development and vulnerability of countries. Thank you.
The third reform of the common fisheries policy must not be allowed to happen again against the interests of fishermen.

No, not all fishermen are 'pirates of the sea' solely responsible for the poor state of health of fish stocks, as some claim by including all categories of fishing, environmental organizations and the European Commission.

It goes without saying that we must preserve fish stocks, but we must also allow our fishermen to make a living from their activity and preserve the economic fabric, dynamism, and cultural identity of our coastal regions.
The main measures taken by the European executive, once again, tend to reduce the number of fishermen in order to achieve the mythical maximum sustainable yield.
I repeat that the French fleet has decreased by more than 50% since 1980.

The Commission proposes, inter alia, the introduction of transferable individual quotas, the obligation to industrialise and concentrate the sector, or even a total ban on discards which professionals consider unrealistic.
This reform project probably suits the industrial fleet but in the current state it would mean the programmed death of what remains of local and artisanal fishing.

The agreed trilogue will allow for a rapid implementation of the Commission decision project, and out of pragmatism, we can only welcome this.
The energy Europe is progressing, not fast certainly but it is progressing.
The European Union is heavily dependent on certain energy supplier countries structurally.

In order to have a more European reflection on our energy strategy, it has become necessary to widely disseminate to the European Commission information related to energy agreements, while respecting the principle of subsidiarity.
The establishment of an information mechanism on intergovernmental agreements will therefore improve transparency in the energy market and allow us to anticipate problems with energy supply.
I am pleased that the present decision does not create obligations as regards commercial company agreements.
In times of crisis and considering competition and competitiveness issues, we should protect our companies' interests and private contract protection rules.

Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues. I would like to start by thanking Mr Gorosti for his excellent report.

We all know that the European Union provides less than half of the total global public development aid, yet with the MDGs approaching their deadline in 2015, even if some targets seem to have been met.
We must ask ourselves how we can improve our aid, make it more consistent with our trade policy, our agricultural policy, and our foreign policy.
The future of European development policy must be based on specific, measurable and timetabled commitments over both short and medium term.

The economic crisis, climate change, the rise of emerging countries, land degradation - these all force us to redefine our priorities: priorities to ensure food security, access to energy resources, and access to healthcare.

There is indeed a European consensus, but we must rethink European and international institutional systems in environmental and social matters, inspired by decision-making bodies such as the WTO, for example.
Finally, and above all, we must explain to our fellow citizens that the development of third countries is not just charity and solidarity, but also a source of development for us.
It suffices to look at the markets that open up to Europeans in emerging countries: China, Brazil and India.
2015 will also be an opportunity to take better account of the strategic evolution of recent years, because today's emerging countries were, not so long ago, developing countries.
These countries should also contribute their share to international aid as an inescapable economic power.
The European Union should be the promoter of responsible development at European and international levels.

The year 2015 will be more than just an end-of-term deadline; it will be a unique opportunity to rethink development aid, not merely as financial assistance but as support for responsible development projects at both the social and environmental levels.

I therefore join my colleagues from other groups and those from the Committee on Economic and Social Affairs and the Committee on Regions in calling for 2015 to be designated the European Year for Development and above all for responsible development.
The agenda for change proposed by the Commission raises many questions in my view, the main one being the concrete implementation of the principle of differentiation.

The Commission wants the choice of countries in which the EU invests its development aid from 2014 onwards to be based on the automatic application of a simple criterion – the average wealth per inhabitant.
As Mrs Malmström said, these issues are not just about accounting, but they deserve a proper political debate on defining our priorities in terms of international cooperation.
Furthermore, this differentiated approach is not, in my view, consistent with the spirit of the Cotonou Agreement.

I am convinced that ACP countries which have achieved positive economic performance should be encouraged in their transition towards more sustainable growth. These countries should not be unfairly sanctioned because they have succeeded in ensuring growth through discipline, good governance and prudent economic policies.
Madam President, Commissioner, let us welcome the initiative taken by Jacques Delors twenty years ago, at a time when there was the fall of the Berlin Wall.
Despite all these advances that we have noted since the beginning of our debate, it is undeniable that ACTA is now synonymous with injustice, inequality, and economic liberalism.
Therefore, I would like to hear from you, Mr Barnier, Commissioner, on how we are going to build together a fairer, more facilitating, protective Europe.

There are several tracks and I would like to hear your views on them, as they are at the heart of the economic and social crisis that we unfortunately know so well: tax harmonisation, public services.
Protectors, minimum wage in Europe, implementation of enhanced cooperation, job creators, facilitation of cross-border cooperation, and develop a fair trade policy.
These are the issues that I believe will be facing us in twenty years' time.
I count on you, Commissioner, to help us carry forward this fine policy of European construction together.

Mr President, as a member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, I have been particularly interested in my colleague Riga Baltsa's report on the main concerns of citizens and businesses over the past two years.
We have discussed this report in connection with our debate on the internal market' s twentieth anniversary.
It has been twenty years since we have recognized that free movement of goods, people, services, and capital should be able to operate freely within our internal market area.

I was particularly interested in the fact that at the first rank of concerns expressed by our European citizens figure the necessity of qualifications and that we really need to be particularly proactive and particularly efficient.

This is what our fellow citizens expect in order genuinely to establish, in the very near future, procedures for recognizing their qualifications, their competence, their professional qualifications which are really faster, simpler, more effective and less costly.
It is a real issue.

As the fictitious rapporteur of the EPP Group on this subject, modernisation of these procedures, I am working actively with other members of the IMCO Committee to truly respond to this major challenge of mobility.
More mobility for more Europe! This is what our fellow citizens want.
The Committee on Petitions has this year gained the right to be automatically associated for the hearing of European citizens' initiatives.
It was the strong signal of 2011 for this commission.
Citizens already had a commission to address non-compliance with their rights, but this is now also the case when they have proposals to improve European legislation.
I hope that the Committee on Petitions can increasingly be regarded as the preferred interlocutor of citizens in the European Parliament.
This consideration problem can also be found in the results of the opinions of the Committee on Petitions.
We are often contacted by citizens who are faced with legal obstacles which we would like to address, but since these problems are European, ...
The solutions should be European, but we remain powerless because subsidiary does not always go hand in hand with European solutions due to lack of national will.
I will take the difficult example of transnational divorces. The problems are both national and European when the rights of custody or visitation exceed national borders, in this case, Germany's.
Despite the difficulties that many parents face in seeing their children born from a binational union, we remain powerless in Parliament to take action.

My proposal that all European citizens should have the right to a national mediator, especially those from Germany who send in a large number of petitions – the model of the French rights defender has not been followed up on.
However, in the case of transnational divorces, this remains a problematic European solution and a national solution.
In many cases, European law seems powerless to respond to citizens' expectations.
The European Year of Citizens should focus on citizens' rights, listening to their concerns but we need means to act in order to be able to.
